Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Discovering Complex Anomalous Mappings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A 2000 report by the Institute of Medicine indicated that 100,000 patients die in the U.S. each year due to suboptimal treatment decisions made by healthcare professionals who operate under pressure of time while processing overwhelming amounts of data, particularly in the operating rooms and intensive care units. Corrective measures and new regulations have not led to improvements yet. In developed countries, about 6% of the economy is spent on upkeep of infrastructure, and about 50% of the original acquisition cost is spent on maintenance of equipment. Managers of, e.g., fleets of aircraft, are too often unable to maintain the required levels of equipment availability due to unexpected, but identifiable in data, crises in maintenance and logistics: only about 2/3 of the U.S. military aircraft can be flown at once. Expediting solutions often causes hundreds of millions in avoidable expenses. These two examples, as well as many other societally, economically, and scientifically important domains of human activity, involve large amounts of multi-stream data, which may carry information helpful in mitigating some of the adversities. Existing research efforts produce algorithms that extract useful information from individual sources of data. Substantial new benefits, however, could be realized by exploiting relationships between streams of data. This research program will comprehensively and pragmatically explore that opportunity, and impact communities of healthcare practitioners, equipment managers, as well as users in other domains wherever multiple streams of corroborative evidence are available, it will also benefit students and trainees, and the scientific community at large.

This research project will develop and extensively evaluate new algorithms to identify informative correlations between multiple and diverse streams of large, multivariate, numeric and symbolic, potentially sparse data. These algorithms will identify subsets of features and records of data that follow distinct cross-stream relationship patterns, enable descriptive and predictive analytics in static and temporal settings, and allow robust forecasts. The proposed work will build on prior efforts towards detection of complex anomalous patterns in single streams of multidimensional data, and expand it towards cross-stream analysis of multiple data sources. Expected results will allow, e.g., detection of patterns of change in relationships between vital signs measured at the bedside of intensive care patients and their records of treatment or medication, and outcomes. These patterns may be indicative of non-standard responses of a patient to a treatment, or signal emergence of a health crisis. In a broader perspective, this effort will substantially expand capabilities of current techniques of cross-stream analytics such as Canonical Correlation Analysis, it will develop a new variant of Gaussian Processes framework to model inter-stream dynamics, produce new information-theoretical modeling of correlations between streams of symbolic variables (with an extension to handle datasets with a mix of numeric and symbolic features), and it will provide a framework for identifying multimodal structures of cross-stream relationships, including disjunctive and conjunctive-disjunctive patterns. It will take on highly challenging intellectual endeavors while aiming for significant benefits of societal importance, with the primary impact demonstration areas in bed-side informatics and equipment health management. Resulting software implementations of the new algorithms and illustrative examples of their use will be shared with the general research community. The bulk of the proposed work will be performed by graduate students and medical fellows who will immediately use the acquired knowledge in their careers. The PIs will include the results in outreach activities and in their training and teaching course materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed and extensively evaluated new algorithms to identify informative correlations between multiple and diverse streams of large, multivariate, potentially sparse data. These algorithms are capable of identifying subsets of features and records of data that follow distinct inter-stream and cross-stream relationship patterns, enable descriptive and predictive analytics in static and temporal settings, and allow robust probabilistic forecasts. This work has built on prior NSF-funded efforts towards detection of complex anomalous patterns in single streams of multidimensional data, and expanded it in multiple ways, primarily towards cross-stream analysis of multiple data sources. Obtained results allow e.g. detection of patterns of change in relationships between vital signs measured at the bedside of an intensive care patients and their record of treatment or medication, and outcomes. These patterns may be indicative of non-standard responses of a patient to a treatment, or signal emergence of a health crisis, and are not identifiable using direct monitoring of individual streams of data.

In a broader perspective, this effort substantially expanded capabilities of prior techniques of cross-stream analytics, developed methods to model inter-stream and intra-stream dynamics, and provided a framework for identifying multimodal structures of cross-stream relationships. Our results will and they already do make impact on multiple applications of science, technology, and medical care. They show a tangible potential to improve the utility of data routinely collected in the practice of clinical medicine, allowing clinicians to be better informed of the status of their patients, so that their diagnoses and treatment decisions could be more accurate, resulting in reduced costs of care and better health outcomes for the patients.

This project has pursued highly challenging intellectual endeavors while aiming for significant benefits of societal importance, with documented impact on demonstration areas in bed-side informatics, equipment health management, nuclear safety, health insurance industry, and countering human trafficking applications. The resulting descriptions and implementations of the new algorithms and illustrative examples of their use have been shared with the general research community, and it is available for licensing and commercialization, and for additional beneficial uses in other fields.

The bulk of the proposed work has been performed by graduate students, post-doctoral and medical fellows who became capable of using the acquired knowledge in their careers. This project has helped expand and solidify the new cohort of young professionals at various levels of competency who either have already or will soon enter the work force and begin applying their acquired knowledge and skills in making impact on daily lives of Americans. Throughout this project, we have involved and mentored 2 post-doctoral researchers, 8 Ph.D. students (2 of whom have graduated with dissertations), 3 master’s students (one graduated with a thesis), 2 undergrads, and 4 non-Ph.D. research staff members.

Our work has been widely disseminated. Project team members gave 35 public presentations of our work, including 6 invited talks, 2 of which were plenary keynotes at scientific conferences. We have published 68 peer reviewed papers, including book 42 journal articles, and 26 papers in scientific conference proceedings. A handful of additional publications are still under peer review. This work has also yielded 2 doctoral theses and 1 master thesis, all directly stemming from the research conducted in this project, and additional 6 doctoral students are working towards their dissertations leveraging work done in this project.

The investigators included the results in several additional outreach activities and in their training and teaching course materials. They are actively using the research results obtained in this project to foster additional research and to develop new collaborations and application opportunities to further leverage the created resources.
